questions.question_text: Which QoS traffic handling technique retains excess packets in a queue and reschedules these packets for later transmission when the configured maximum bandwidth has been surpassed?

comments.content:
Yes, and also importantly:

"with the police command, it is not an option to buffer the packet and later send it out, as is the case for the shape command."

discussion.content: Policing drops or remarks traffic that exceeds limits, but shaping regulates the traffic back to a defined rate by delaying or queuing the traffic.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
I concur with option D because it keeps it for later transmission

Selected Answer: D
Given answer is correct.

Selected Answer: D
of couse D is right

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

questions.question_text: Which command must be entered to configure a DHCP relay?

choices.B: Configure ip dhcp relay information option command on the interface that is connected to the DHCP server.
choices.A: Configure the ip dhcp snooping trust command on the interface that is connected to the DHCP client.
choices.C: Configure ip dhcp snooping trust command on the interface that is connected to the DHCP server.
choices.D: Configure the ip dhcp information option command on the interface that is connected to the DHCP client.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
If a Layer 2 LAN port is connected to a DHCP server, configure the port as trusted by entering the ip dhcp snooping trust interface configuration command.
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/general/Test/dwerblo/broken_guide/snoodhcp.html#wp1073367

Selected Answer: C
Configure the ports that are connected to a DHCP server or to other switches or routers as trusted ports.
Configure the ports that are connected to DHCP clients as untrusted ports
At times you get the answer by eliminating options that you know can never be right.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

questions.question_text:
A network analyst is tasked with configuring the date and time on a router using EXEC mode. The date must be set to January 1, 2020 and the time must be set to
12:00 am. Which command should be used?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Option 'd' is correct:

The following commands are set FIRST, at the global configuration mode:
E.g.:
clock timezone NZST 12
clock summer-time NZDT recurring last Sun Sept 2:00 first Sun April 3:00

Only then, at privileged exec:
clock set

There is not clock summer-time-recurring command.

Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/smb/switches/cisco-small-business-300-series-managed-switches/smb5584-configure-system-time-settings-on-a-switch-through-the-comma.html

Selected Answer: D
clock set is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct: clock set hh:mm:ss day month year

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. What is the metric of the route to the 192.168.10.33/28 subnet?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
193 is the metric, 110 is the AD

Selected Answer: D
itÂ´s D

Selected Answer: D
193 is the metric, 110 is the AD

Selected Answer: D
I at least now know the difference between AD/ Metric [110/193] in this example
its lovely to have a few questions that are clear and make sense.

he metric of the route to the 192.168.10.32/28 subnet is 110, not 193.

The metric is the administrative distance, which is a value that indicates the preference of a route. The lower the metric, the more preferred the route is.

In this case, the metric of 110 is the sum of the administrative distance of the serial interface (84) and the cost of the path to the next hop (26).

The administrative distance of a serial interface is typically 84, while the cost of the path to the next hop is typically the number of hops to the next hop. In this case, the next hop is 192.168.30.10, which is one hop away.

Therefore, the metric of the route to the 192.168.10.32/28 subnet is 110.


"this is because the output is using a Cisco IOS-style format"
**Cisco IOS-style format:**
[metric]/[administrative distance] [destination network] [via next hop]

**Other styles:**
[administrative distance]/[metric] [destination network] [via next hop]

comments.content: 110 is the Administrative Distance while 193 is the metric. Metric is used to break the tire between two or more routes which have the same AD. correct answer is D

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
110 is AD, 193 is metric

Selected Answer: D
110 AD

Selected Answer: D
I think D is correct, 110 AD
